title: Dan Carter returns to NZ on pre-planned holiday ahead of drink driving legal proceedings in France
text:
Dan Carter returns to NZ on pre-planned holiday ahead of drink driving legal proceedings in France Last updated 10:52, February 18 2017 1 NEWS 
French news outlet L'Equipe rugby writer Richard Escot says Dan Carter remains popular with rugby fans in Paris. 
Dan Carter has returned to New Zealand on a pre-planned holiday as he awaits legal proceedings for a drink driving offence committed in central Paris this week. 
The All Blacks great revealed online on Saturday that he had returned to New Zealand, as he again commented on the "mistake" he had made on Wednesday night (NZT Thursday), when he was caught by police drink driving. 
"Just got back to NZ for what was supposed to be a fun pre planned holiday. Seeing the family again puts fresh perspective on just how big a mistake I made. #dontdrinkanddrive ," Carter wrote on Facebook. John Clifton/ Reuters 
All Blacks great Dan Carter has admitted to a "massive error" after French police caught him allegedly drink driving in central Paris. 
READ MORE: * Nonu staying in France, re-signs with Toulon 
The message followed a comment on Friday (NZ time) in which Carter admitted to a "massive error" in the French capital where he was reported by Closer to have been found by police with 0.98g of alcohol in his system for every litre of blood. 
The legal alcohol limit in France for a driver was 0.5g per litre. Carter was also reported to have been driving without his licence. He was not detained or arrested when police stopped him near the famous downtown street the Champs-Elysees. 
The three-time World Player of the Year first admitted to the mistake on Thursday. 
"I am sure a lot of you have seen the headlines. No excuses - I made a massive error of judgment and have let down my club, my fans and most importantly my family," Carter said on Facebook. Ad Feedback 
"I will have to now let the police/court process run its course and face the consequences. I am just glad no one was harmed. Sorry." 
The maximum penalty in France for a drink driving offence of this scale was a two-year prison sentence and a fine of â‚¬4500 (NZ$6900), as well as six penalty points against the driver's licence. 
With the 34-year-old recovering from injury and his Paris rugby club Racing 92 on a break for the Six Nations international competition, he was allowed to return home with his family. 
He was among rugby's greatest players having 112 test caps with the All Blacks and an international career points tally of 1598. 
FAN REACTION 
Carter's drink driving admission was met with a mixed response from his online followers.
